economic  activities  in  the  project  area,  provide  employment

social services.

The  Project  will  (i)  reduce  travel  time  between  Noi  Bai  and  Lao 
Cai from 7–10 hours to 3–4 hours, (ii) reduce the volume of traffic 
passing  through  cities  and  towns  in  the  project  area,  (iii)  reduce 
the  transport  distance  for  container  and  other  freight,  (iv)  allow 
operations  of  frequent  long-distance  bus  services  along  the 
highway and feeder public transportation services connecting the 
highway bus stops to communes, (v) reduce the number of traffic 
accidents, (vi) generate toll revenue to cover debt service of VEC, 
and  (vii)  create  small  and  medium  businesses  and  generate 
employment opportunities for local people.

The major project beneficiaries will be (i) highway users, including 
cargo  forwarders,  bus  operators,  and  tourists;  (ii)  local  residents, 
who  will  benefit  from  improved  mobility  and  lower  prices  of 
commodities and transport services; (iii) local laborers involved in 
the  construction  works  and  supply  of  materials  during  project 
implementation  and  later  in  operation  of  the  highway;  (vi)  local 
and  international  manufacturers  and  traders,  who  will  be  able  to 
establish  new  businesses  and  increase  production  capacity,  (v) 
VEC,  who  will  receive  toll  revenue  from  highway  users;  (vi)  bus 
operators,  who  will  be  able  to  expand  their  businesses;  and  (vii) 
port authorities in north Viet Nam, who will benefit from increased 
cargo volume. 
 
VEC’s human resources and organizational structure are currently 
inadequate  to  implement  a  large-scale  highway  construction 
project. The lack of knowledge of and experience with safeguards, 
corporate  finance,  and  highway  O&M  are  of  particular  concern. 
The project supervision consultant will provide on-the-job training 
to VEC staff.  
 
One concern is potential project implementation delays caused by 
delayed  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  delayed  procurement, 
and/or  poor  performance  of  the  contractors.  To  avoid  project 
implementation  delays, 
following 
approaches:  (i)  notice  to  commence  civil  works  on  a  particular 
section will be issued only when land acquisition and resettlement 
have been satisfactorily completed; (ii) VEC will proceed with the 
initial  steps  of  procurement  of  the  civil  works  before  signing  the 
Loan and Project Agreements; and (iii) prequalification of bidders 
will be undertaken to eliminate bidders that lack the technical and 
financial capacity to implement highway construction contracts of 
this size and complexity.   
 
The  highway’s  construction  will  involve  a  large  amount  of 
embankment  construction  and  excavation,  acquisition  of 
residential  and  agricultural  lands,  and  resettlement  of  project-
affected people, although the final alignment has been developed 
to  ensure  that  environmentally  sensitive  areas  are  avoided  and 
involuntary  resettlement  is  kept  to  a  minimum.  An  environmental 
impact assessment was undertaken, and a full resettlement plan, 
including  an  ethnic  minority  development  plan,  was  prepared  to 
mitigate these risks. 
 
The  Project  will  increase  road  traffic  and  mobility  of  goods  and 
people, and consequently could increase HIV incidence, illicit drug 
use,  and  human  trafficking  in  local  communities.  The  Project  will 
include a technical assistance component to minimize these risks. 
Accidents  between  highway  users  and  the  local  people  may 
occur, in particular in the early period of highway operation, since 
there  is  limited  experience  in  Viet  Nam  with  access-controlled

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on proposed loans

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

The  Kunming–Hai  Phong  Transport  Corridor  consists  of  multiple  transport  modes, 
2. 
namely  road,  rail,  and  inland  waterway.  To  meet  the  growing  transport  demand  in  the  project 
area, possible alternatives to transport infrastructure projects were considered. The alternatives 
were  reviewed  based  on  travel  time,  alignments,  technical  designs,  social  and  environmental 
impacts,  and  economic  and  financial  viability.  The  analysis  concluded  that  constructing  the 
proposed Noi Bai–Lao Cai Highway, and rehabilitating and upgrading the existing railway—for 
which  ADB  approved  a  loan  in  2006 1—are  important  for  the  corridor  development.(cid:31)F
2 While  the 
railway project is expected to partly meet the increasing transport demand, it will not completely 
satisfy  the  demand  for  all  the  various  kinds  of  traffic—particularly  passenger  traffic  and  high-
value  general  cargo  traffic,  which  require  a  more  flexible  and  responsive  mode  to  meet  the 
needs of a market economy. The Project was proposed to satisfy these needs. 
 
The  Noi  Bai–Lao  Cai  Highway  is  an  integral  section  of  the  eastern  link  of  the  GMS 
3. 
Northern Economic Corridor, connecting Kunming in Yunnan province of the People’s Republic 
of  China  (PRC)  with  Hanoi  and  Hai  Phong  in  Viet  Nam.  In  Yunnan  province,  a  400-kilometer

bridges, and has substantial ribbon development on most sections. These factors severely limit

in  traffic  demand  in  the  corridor.  The  section  of  the  highway  from  Noi  Bai  to  Hanoi  and  Hai 
Phong  has  been  improved  with  assistance  from  other  external  donor  agencies.  Only  the  Noi 
Bai–Lao Cai section needs to be upgraded to complete the Kunming–Hai Phong Highway. The 
project  feasibility  study  confirmed  the  necessity  and  viability  of  a  modern  highway  linking  the

and  Viet  Nam  have  become  important  trade  partners.  Cross-border  trade  between  Yunnan

Agreement  at  the  Hekou–Lao  Cai  border  crossing  points  have  been  finalized.  In  addition, 
agreement has been reached by the two governments to consider, at the earliest possible time, 
expanding  the  scope  of  the  existing  bilateral  road  transport  agreement  to  include  the  entire 
Kunming–Hanoi–Hai Phong transport corridor as an interim measure until the relevant annexes 
and  protocols  of  the  GMS  Cross-Border  Transport  Agreement  have  been  ratified.  This  will 
facilitate  the  exchange  of  commercial  traffic  rights  along  the  corridor,  which  would  reduce  the 
incidence  of  costly  and  time-consuming  transshipment  at  the  Hekou–Lao  Cai  border  crossing 
points. 
 
6. 
The passage of containerized freight is particularly important for the trading relationship. 
Forwarders of overseas container cargo in Kunming do not currently use the Kunming–Hekou–
Lao  Cai–Hanoi–Hai  Phong  route,  partly  because  of  the  poor  condition  of  the  Lao  Cai–Hanoi 
section in Viet Nam, inefficient custom control procedures at the Hekou–Lao Cai border, and the 
high  cost  of  transshipping  containers  at  the  border  crossing.  Instead,  they  send  container 
cargos  by  rail  or  road  to  the  large  ports  in  Guangzhou  province  (PRC),  which  takes  up  to 
6 days, and by road to the nearest ports in Guangxi province (PRC), which is about 1,050 km 
from  Kunming.  The  proposed  Noi  Bai–Lao  Cai  Highway  will  allow  forwarders  in  Kunming  to 
reach Hai Phong and Cai Lan ports, which contain large container facilities, in 1 day. Once the 
proposed  Noi  Bai–Lao  Cai  Highway  has  been  completed,  and  the  ADB-supported  border 
crossing  operation  is  streamlined,  a  substantial  number  of  containers  originating  in  Kunming 
could  be  diverted  to  the  Kunming–Hai  Phong  route.  Viet  Nam  would  benefit  from  this  through 
transit and port fees, among other benefits. 
 
7.

26. 
Subregional  Highway  Network  Development.  Entry  of  PRC  traffic  into  Viet  Nam  is 
limited to the Lao Cai border area at present. Likewise, entry of Vietnamese traffic into the PRC 
is limited to the Hekou border area. Freight is transshipped by workers from truck to truck at the 
border  areas.  This  results  in  high  transportation  costs  and  longer  haulage  times.  The  GMS 
transport corridor concept, of which the highway is an integral section, will enhance social and 
economic  activities  by  removing  border-crossing  barriers.  The  governments  of  Viet  Nam  and 
PRC agreed to implement the GMS Cross-Border Transport Agreement for the Lao Cai–Hekou 
border,  which  streamlines  cross-border  operations  and  grants  transit  traffic  rights  for  traffic 
transiting  to  or  from  the  territory  of  other  signatories  of  the  Agreement.  Travel  time  on  the 
current  Kunming–Hai  Phong  route  currently  averages  about  2  days  for  passenger  cars  and  3 
days for trucks. The proposed highway will reduce travel times between Hanoi and Lao Cai from 
7  hours  to  3  hours  for  passenger  cars,  and  from  10  hours  to  4  hours  for  trucks.  Taking  into 
consideration  expressway  construction  in  Yunnan  Province,  and  the  streamlining  of  cross-
border operations, travel from Kunming to Hai Phong will be reduced to about 1 day once the 
project highway is completed. This decrease in travel time and cost could induce international 
freight  originating  in  Kunming  to  shift  from  PRC  ports  to  Viet  Nam  ports  via  the  Kunming–Hai 
Phong  Transport  Corridor,  and  consequently  encourage  economic  activities  in  the  project 
provinces.

Nam  is  the  country’s  poorest.  In  2004,  the  portion  of  the  area’s  population  living  below  the 
poverty  line  was  about  52%,  compared  with  a  countrywide  average  of  23%.  Much  of  this 

8 

 

 difference reflects the lack of access of the western portion of the project area to major areas of 
economic  activity,  employment  opportunities,  etc,  which  the  project  highway  will  substantially 
improve.  From  a  subregional  perspective,  the  ADF  allocation  supports  the  connection  of  two 
economically  dominant  areas—Hanoi–Hai  Phong  and  Kunming—through  a  hinterland  that  is 
much less developed. The specific benefit of the ADF allocation for both of these objectives is 
that initial toll levels on the project highway will be significantly lower than would be the case if 
only  nonconcessional  financing  were  provided.  By  softening  the  terms  of  the  total  project 
financing, the toll levels can be lowered to socially acceptable levels, and thus the highway can 
be accessible to a much wider section of the population, while maintaining the financial viability 
of VEC and the Project.

Ports Capacity. Hai Phong and Cai Lan are major ports in northern Viet Nam. The Hai 
Phong port has a planned capacity of 6 million tons per year for cargo throughput and 550,000 
twenty-foot equivalent units per year for container throughput. Only midsized vessels can enter 
the port because of its shallow depth. The port mainly serves Southeast Asia. Freight traffic at 
the port is reaching its capacity. The Cai Lan port has a capacity of 15 million tons per year for 
cargo  throughput.  Large-size  vessels  can  enter  the  port,  and  it  serves  destinations  outside 
Southeast  Asia.  The  volume  of  cargo  handled  in  2006  was  about  1.5  million  tons,  and  the 
volume of containers was about 110,000 twenty-foot equivalent units. Since land transport costs 
were higher because of its geographic disadvantage compared to Hai Phong port, the Cai Lan 
port still has sufficient cargo and container handling capacity. The improved National Road 18 
connects  Noi  Bai  to  these  ports.  Completion  of  the  Bai  Chay  Bridge  on  National  Road  18  in 
2006  effectively  removed  the  geographical  disadvantage  of  the  Cai  Lan  port.  The  Project’s 
traffic  demand  forecast  indicates  that  the  growth  rate  of  freight  volume  will  accelerate  to  an 
annual rate of 4.6–6.1% by 2022. It is expected that these ports will be able to accommodate 
the increased trading demand.

international trade center and Kim Thanh free trade zone are being constructed in the Lao Cai

Development  of  highway  and  expressway  networks  is  one  of  the  most  effective 
approaches  to  improving  road  safety  and  reducing  the  number  of  traffic  accidents.  Accident 
rates on access-controlled highways and expressways are much lower than that on access-free 
general roads. The Project ensures that all important safety measures are in place. Independent 
road  safety  audits  of  the  project  roads  will  be  carried  out  during  final  design  and  construction 
and before the opening of the project highway. Axle-weighing equipment will be installed at the 
Noi  Bai  and  Lao  Cai  interchanges  to  control  vehicle  overloading  in  the  corridor.  VEC  will 
concentrate on the engineering, the road safety audit, blind-spot improvement, and operational 
issues, while the police will deal with traffic law enforcement.

About 1 million tons of cargo is transported annually across the Hekou–Lao Cai border 
crossing  points.  The  daily  truck  volume  observed  at  the  border  is  approximately  100.  Two-
wheeled carts are also broadly used for trading vegetables and fruits. PRC trucks are currently 
allowed to go inside Lao Cai city to transship their cargos to the Vietnamese trucks, and vice-
versa. Transshipment increases transport cost. The governments of Viet Nam and PRC agreed 
to begin implementing the Cross-Border Transport Agreement on the Hekou–Lao Cai border in 
September  2007.  This  will  result  in  new  procedures.  The  opening  of  the  border  crossing  to 
international  through  traffic,  which  will  enable  qualified  vehicles  and  operators  to  continue 
through  to  destination,  is  one  major  change  in  the  nature  of  operations.  The  formalities  and 
procedures will continue in much the same way as before, but will be streamlined to ensure that 
immigration, custom clearance, and quarantine be processed at a single window of the border 
facilities. Consequently, transport costs and travel times will be reduced in both countries, and 
trading volume and traffic volume will increase substantially.

Expressways are high-speed divided highways with access controlled, and should have 
4 or more lanes to allow fast traffic to overtake slow traffic. The two-lane structure for the Yen 
Bai–Lao Cai section of the highway is not an expressway. However, construction of a two-lane 
highway  designed  to  the  expressway  standard,  as  a  tentative  configuration,  in  medium  traffic 
demand areas is a reasonable approach. Compared to the configuration of expressways, a two-
lane highway still has some disadvantages. Overtaking slower traffic is allowed only on limited 
sections. The design capacity of two-lane highways is 20,000 vehicles per day (passenger car 
unit),  which  is  only  25%  of  four-lane  highways.  The  risk  of  accidents  on  two-lane  highways  is 
much  lower  than  on  general  roads,  as  access  to  the  highway  is  controlled.  However,  there 
remains a risk of head-on collisions caused by reckless overtaking. Construction of an additional 
two lanes should be considered within 10 years of the project highway’s opening.

and Haiphong in Viet Nam. The highway traverses the provinces of Vinh Phu, Phu Tho, Yen Bai, and Lao Cai towards 
the Chinese border in the north. The total population of these provinces is 6.9 million (2005). Females represent 51.3% 
of the total population in the project area and ethnic minorities represent 18.3% of the population, although in the upland 
provinces of Yen Bai and Lao Cai ethnic minorities represent 35.6% of the population. However, ethnic minority groups 
constitute only 2.44% of the households affected by resettlement activities. The average age of the people in the project 
area  is  47  years,  compared  to  the  national  average  of  42  years.  According  to  social  assessment  in  the  project  area, 
more than 28.05% of the population is under 15 and 43% of the population is aged between 15 and 45. In the lowland 
Red  River  Delta  provinces  (Phu  Tho,  Vinh  Phuc,  and  Hanoi)  all  people  surveyed  had  completed  6  years  of  primary 
schooling irrespective of their gender and ethnicity. In the upland provinces of Yen Bai and Lao Cai, many people have 
also  completed  6  years  of  primary  schooling.  All  these  people  are  functionally  literate  in  the  Vietnamese  language. 
Access  to  secondary  school  at  the  district  level  is  a  major  problem  for  upland  people.  Health  indicators  in  the  project 
area are not good in terms of upper respiratory tract infections and lung infections. Diarrhea and dysentery are common

costs constrain the ability of upland people to seek quality medical service. Agriculture in both lowland and upland areas 
includes both rice crops and cash crops. Households in the upland areas also grow cash crops, rice, cassava, maize, 
tea, etc. Wage labor in the project area is another income earning strategy for poor households. In addition, economic 
activities such as fishing, aquaculture, collection of non-timber forest products, and small business are part of the rural 
livelihood. According to the social assessment there is substantial poverty in the project area. The Yen Bai province is 
the poorest in the project area. The poverty level is higher in the upland provinces than in the lowland provinces.

as well as in the capital city. However, the extent to which the people in the project area can take advantage of these 
services depends on further improvement of the provincial road network and rural access roads.  
 
Additional project impacts relate to (i) displacement of a large number of households because of land acquisition; (ii) loss 
of productive land; (iii) increased traffic risks for people living and working along the road because of large volumes of 
traffic and higher vehicle speeds along the expressway; (iv) increased risks of exposure to HIV and trafficking of women 
and children during the construction and post-construction phases (because of the large volumes of transit traffic along

The project resettlement policy and entitlements have been developed from the laws of 
the  Government  of  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam,  principally  the  Constitution  (1992)  that 
confirms  the  right  of  citizens  to  own  and  protect  the  ownership  of  a  house;  Land  Law  No.

recovery by the State, as amended by Decree No. 17/2006/ND-CP; Decree No. 188/2004/ND-
CP,  specifying  the  methods  for  land  pricing  and  land  price  frameworks  in  the  event  of  land 
recovery by the State; and ADB’s Involuntary Resettlement Policy (1995) guided by Operations 
Manual  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (2006).  Provisions  and  principles  adopted  in  this  Project

exists, consistent with Decree No. 131/2006/ND-CP, which provides that in case of “discrepancy 
between any provision in an international treaty  on Official Development Assistance (ODA), to 
which the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam is a signatory, and the Vietnamese Law, the provision 
in the international treaty on ODA shall take precedence” (Article 2, Item 5).

compensation  is  based  on  the  principle  of  replacement  cost.  Compensation  and  provision  of

displacement of affected households from their houses, land, and assets, such that they will be 
at  least  as  well  off  as  they  would  have  been  in  the  absence  of  the  Project,  and  the  poorest 
affected  households  and  vulnerable  groups,  including  affected  persons  from  ethnic  minorities,
